htmlmodule.label: large_fires_header
htmlmodule.content:
Kittitas County:

a Fire Environment

textfield.placeholder: Your email address will never be shared
textfield.prompt: Enter your email address to make sure you get information about an onsite wildfire consultation at the end of this survey. You'll learn about your wildfire risk and forest conditions:

htmlmodule.label: large_fires_information
htmlmodule.content:
Kittitas County is in the heart of fire-prone country. 36 large fires have burned here since 1973.

Click on fires on the map to learn more about them, and use the slider in the lower left to explore the changing wildfire risk in central Washington.

Large wildfires in Kittitas County
Large wildfires elsewhere in Washington
36Large wildfires started since 1973227,533Total acres burned

htmlmodule.label: forest_type_header
htmlmodule.content: Changing Forest Conditions

radiofield.prompt: On your land, which forest type is predominant? (See below for descriptions and images of forest types.)

htmlmodule.label: forest_type_information
htmlmodule.content:
Subalpine: Subalpine fir generally occupies colder, higher elevation mountain forests. Fires are typically stand-replacing events at approximately 200-year or greater intervals. When wildfire occurs, this forest is more susceptible to high intensity crown fires.

Fire return interval200+ years

Moist Mix Conifer: Forests of grand fir, white fir, and Douglas-fir with an average fire return interval of 45-100 years. When wildfire occurs in this forest type it can vary from medium to high severity.

Fire return interval45-100 years

Dry Forest: A forest dominated by ponderosa pine, with understory conifers like Douglas Fir and Grand Fir. Lack of wildfire can result in dense stands highly susceptible to medium to high intensity fires. The wildfire return intervals are 15-25 years.

Fire return interval15-25 years

Ponderosa Pine: Straddles the line between rangelands and forest with an overstory of ponderosa pine trees and an understory of shrubs, grasses, and forbs. Wildfires were historically common in this forest type, with return intervals of 8-15 years.

Fire return interval8-15 years

Non-forest Rangeland: Rangeland (shrub steppe with sagebrush and grasses) with fire intervals of 5-15 years. When wildfire occurs in this land cover type, the severity is dependent on the vegetation density and weather (wind-driven).

Fire return interval5-15 years

htmlmodule.label: fire_risk_header
htmlmodule.content: Kittitas County Wildfire Risk

htmlmodule.label: fire_risk_information
htmlmodule.content:
Wildfire risk varies throughout Kittitas County. The probability of wildfire is based on historical fires, vegetation and public safety.

Severe risk

Low risk

This map shows general wildfire risk. Wind-blown embers generated during wildfires are the single biggest hazard wildfires pose to homes. So Look at the risk level not just where your home is located but at least in a one mile radius to better understand your risk from these burning pieces of airborne wood and/or vegetation.

This map also shows large wildfires and individual wildfire start sites from the last several years. Click on a start site to learn more about it.

htmlmodule.label: fire_resources_header
htmlmodule.content: Kittitas County Fire Resources

geocodingfield.placeholder: Your address will never be shared

htmlmodule.label: fire_resources_information
htmlmodule.content:
Kittitas County has numerous fire resources you should be aware of, including fire districts and Firewise USA communities.

Search for your address above (or zoom and scroll the map) to explore resources in your area.

If you know your tax parcel number but not your address, go to https://gis.co.kittitas.wa.us/compas/default.aspx and enter your parcel number to find more information including the "situs" address.

If your property resides in a fire district, it does not guarantee that the fire district or fire department will be able to defend your property during a wildfire event.

htmlmodule.label: fire_resiliency_header
htmlmodule.content: Your Path to Wildfire Resilience

htmlmodule.label: fire_resiliency_information
htmlmodule.content:
Be resilient! As a landowner in a fire environment, what you do (and don't do!) on your property matters.

Tell us a bit about your property and practices, and we'll send you a customized report with fire resiliency resources and other information.

We'll ask about your fire resiliency practices in three zones around your property:

  • Immediate Zone: 0 - 5 feet from house
  • Intermediate Zone: 5 - 30 feet from house
  • Extended Zone: 30 - 100 feet from house

htmlmodule.label: immediate_zone_header
htmlmodule.content: Immediate Zone Actions

htmlmodule.label: immediate_zone_information
htmlmodule.content: The immediate zone extends to 5 feet from your house. This zone is the most vulnerable to embers. Start here with your fire resiliency efforts.

radiofield.prompt: I clean roofs and gutters of dead leaves, debris and pine needles that could catch embers and I keep my roof in good repair.
radiofield.label: Clean roofs and gutters

radiofield.prompt: I replace or repair any loose or missing shingles or roof tiles to prevent ember penetration
radiofield.label: Replace or repair loose shingles

radiofield.prompt: I reduce embers that could pass through vents by installing 1/8 inch metal mesh screening on foundations and/or exterior attic vents.
radiofield.label: Reduce embers

radiofield.prompt: I clean debris from exterior attic vents and install 1/8 inch metal mesh screening to reduce embers
radiofield.label: Clean debris from attic vents

radiofield.prompt: I’ve screened in areas below patios and decks with wire mesh to prevent debris and combustible materials from accumulating
radiofield.label: Repair or replace window screens

radiofield.prompt: I’ve moved any flammable material away from wall exteriors--mulch, flammable plants, leaves and needles, firewood piles--anything that can burn as well as anything stored underneath decks or porches.
radiofield.label: Move flammable material

htmlmodule.label: intermediate_zone_header
htmlmodule.content: Intermediate Zone Actions

htmlmodule.label: intermediate_zone_information
htmlmodule.content: The intermediate zone extends between 5 and 30 feet from your house. In this zone, using careful landscaping or hardscaping techniques to create fuel breaks can help decrease fire behavior.

radiofield.prompt: I clear vegetation from under and in a 5-foot perimeter around my propane tank
radiofield.label: Clear vegetation from propane tanks

radiofield.prompt: I’ve created fuel breaks with driveways, walkways/paths, patios, and decks
radiofield.label: Create fuel breaks

radiofield.prompt: I keep lawns and native grasses mowed to a height of four inches
radiofield.label: Keep lawns mowed to four inches

radiofield.prompt: I prune tree limbs so the lowest branches are 6 to 10 feet above the ground to help reduce the chance of fire getting into the crowns of the trees
radiofield.label: Remove ladder fuels

radiofield.prompt: I space trees to have a minimum of 18 feet between crowns, with the distance increasing with the percentage of slope
radiofield.label: Space trees to eighteen feet

radiofield.prompt: I ensure that mature tree canopy is no closer than ten feet to the edge of any structures on my property
radiofield.label: Keep tree canopy ten feet from structures

radiofield.prompt: I ensure that trees and shrubs in the intermediate zone are limited to small clusters of a few each to break up the continuity of vegetation
radiofield.label: Break up continuity of vegetation

htmlmodule.label: extended_zone_header
htmlmodule.content: Extended Zone Actions

htmlmodule.label: extended_zone_information
htmlmodule.content: From your home, this zone extends out 30 to 100 feet or even 200 feet if on a slope. The goal here is not to eliminate fire but to interrupt fire’s path and keep flames smaller and on the ground.

radiofield.prompt: I dispose of heavy accumulations of ground litter and debris
radiofield.label: Dispose of ground debris

radiofield.prompt: I regularly remove dead plant and tree material
radiofield.label: Remove dead plant material

radiofield.prompt: I remove small conifers growing between mature trees
radiofield.label: Remove small conifers between mature trees

radiofield.prompt: I remove vegetation adjacent to storage sheds or other outbuildings
radiofield.label: Remove adjacent outbuilding vegetation

radiofield.prompt: I ensure that trees 30 to 60 feet from the home have at least 12 feet between canopy tops
radiofield.label: Space canopy tops 30 to 60 feet from the house

radiofield.prompt: I ensure that trees 60 to 100 feet from the home have at least 6 feet between the canopy tops
radiofield.label: Space canopy tops 60 to 100 feet from the house

htmlmodule.label: emergency_evacuation_header
htmlmodule.content: Emergency and Evacuation Planning

radiofield.prompt: I have an emergency kit
radiofield.label: Evacuation plan

radiofield.prompt: I have an evacuation plan that includes escape routes (preferably 2), a designated family meeting location, and a communication plan
radiofield.label: Evacuation plan

radiofield.prompt: I have an emergency kit prepared with water, food, clothes, flashlight, first aid kit, etc.
radiofield.label: Food and water

radiofield.prompt: I have my important family documents, bank and credit card information, identification, prescriptions, etc. in one location easily accessible during an evacuation
radiofield.label: Copies of documents

radiofield.prompt: I have an evacuation plan for my pets, large animals or livestock
radiofield.label: Evacuation plan

radiofield.prompt: I’ve signed up for the emergency notification system through the Kittitas County Sheriff’s Office or I know where to go for official information
radiofield.label: Food and water

htmlmodule.label: hub_information
htmlmodule.content:
What is a hub?

Hubs are preferred parking areas for bikeshare bicycles. These are places where bikeshare users are encouraged to park when ending a trip and where Lime relocates bikes to provide convenient and reliable service.

Hubs are marked with white boxes and symbols painted on sidewalks or street shoulders, and they are shown in operators’ mobile apps.

htmlmodule.label: hub_location_information
htmlmodule.content:
Where should hubs go?

Anywhere you want to go by bike! We’re aiming to provide a network of conveniently located hubs citywide. Suggest locations in your neighborhood, outside your workplace, at your local park, near your favorite café, restaurants, and shops.

If you don’t see a suggested location in the half-mile (solid) or quarter-mile (dashed) grid squares near places you want to use bikeshare, that is an especially good place to suggest one.

htmlmodule.label: existing_hubs_information
htmlmodule.content:
Existing hubs

Hubs have already been installed at 50 locations across the city, including in Downtown, Crossroads, Factoria, and near major bus stops and community spaces.

Toggle these with the Existing Hubs layer.

htmlmodule.label: bicycle_network_information
htmlmodule.content:
Bicycle network

Not sure where to ride? Toggle the Bike Network layer to see where bike lanes and offstreet paths are near where you want to go.

htmlmodule.label: access_to_transit_information
htmlmodule.content:
Access to transit

Bikeshare can help people get to and from transit more quickly. By locating hubs within walking distance of frequent bus routes, buses and bikeshare can both be more useful.

This map shows the quarter-mile walkshed around Bellevue's frequent transit network.

htmlmodule.label: submission_info
htmlmodule.content:
What do you think?

Drag and zoom the map to let us know where you think we should add a bikeshare hub! Fill out the form below to give us some more information about your suggestion:

filefield.label: Add image
filefield.prompt: Have an image of this location? Add it!
